TopicTitle: The Venturer Program: Tour of the planets

Articles.Content:
CHAPTER 48: VALL

Half an hour later...

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Everything looks good. I think we're ready to go.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Let's see if we can hit that spot there, eh? It seems like a decent place to set down.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'll do my best. And before you say anything, I know we've only got one shot at this.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Not that you'll mess up, I'm sure.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I probably will, now. Never mind, sit back and we'll be down there soon enough.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“A little rickety, don't you think?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That transfer stage has been out here for years. I wouldn't be surprised if a few of its stabilisers are busted.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's reassuring.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Whatever it is, it's nothing, the ASAS is keeping us steady. We're almost done, anyway.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“There, see? We're done for the moment. I'll throttle back up in about 5 minutes.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Gotcha... ugh, it's disconcerting doing a de-orbit facing prograde. And then we've got to swing the lander around after undocking.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I can handle it. I'll bring us to a stop before separating us, just to be safe.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good idea.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It looks nice from up here. Just... no mountains this time, please. I wasn't comfortable with the mountain landing on Moho, and there was less gravity there than there is here.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“The sides are too steep too land on here, anyway.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I thought they were just hills on Moho?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, well, you weren't with us on that mission.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I guess so.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You sure? We're heading for a mountain right now, Ed.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm sure. I'd rather not be marooned on a snowball orbiting a green clump of gas.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then, I'll divert.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Just set us down in the plains ahead.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I was going to.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm ready to undock us from the descent stage, by the way.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Just a moment... ok, do it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“...We're clear.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Got it, swinging around.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“200 metres to go.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nice and flat, from what I can tell...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“150.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I appreciate the thought Bill, but I don't need a commentary.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No problem.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Touchdown in 10 seconds...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Engine cut-off, we're here.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nice work.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We're on a hill... ok then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It's no mountain.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, I know, I know. I just thought the terrain would be less, uh, hazardous for landing. Never mind, you did a good job.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks. So, who's going out first. Bill?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'll go, unless either of you want to do so.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Highest ranking officer first.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Very well. Here goes...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Pretty, very pretty. I'll go ahead and plant the flag.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Got it.Ã¢â‚¬Â
Did the descent stage make it?

Did the descent stage make it?

Crashed, as planned. There was no need to keep it around and no way to save it once its usefulness was expended. It did its job, and did it well, and you can see it blowing up here:

CHAPTER 49: BARREN

Meanwhile, on Laythe...

Jeb: *Heavy breathing* Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hngh... ugh...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“AGH!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ow, geez... Kod, mother of... frakking son of a... agh! Come on, you're nearly at the lake, Jeb. Nearly there... ow... computer, suit status?Ã¢â‚¬Â

EVA Comp.: [sUIT NOMINAL. MINOR DISRUPTION IN COOLING SYSTEM DETECTED]

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good, that hotfix is still Ã¢â‚¬â€œ ow Ã¢â‚¬â€œ working. I'll stay warm no matter what, now-OWÃ¢â‚¬Â

Agh, I think I broke my hand... OW! Yep, something's had it in there. Great. This lake, though... damn, it's beautiful. I think a little swim is in order.

Where did I put those vials. Please don't tell me I smashed them when my clumsy ass landed on them... oh, thank Kod, there they are. Laythe water samples, here I come. I just hope there aren't any fish in here that are peckish.

Now for some of the shoreline sand. Strange, it's not much like Kerbin at all, this stuff. No powdery grains, just clumps of mud and melting ice, with some sand mixed in. Weird. Well, that's the samples sorted out. Now to hike back up this hill. Eep.

You know what? No. I'll just call the Sparrowhawk here.

It's occurred to me that maybe I shouldn't have taken my helmet off earlier. Laythe so far has proven to be somewhat, ah, sterile. Devoid. Barren. I'm the only living thing here. Alone. Except for the microbes that hitched a ride in my suits atmosphere and my breath. I just exposed an unexplored moon that has the potential to support life to... well, life.

Ain't I a clever man? I'll have to blast the area with radiation, but short of dismantling an RTG or the rocket on the plane, I'm fresh out of ideas.

Ah, here's my ride. I could probably dint the RTGs a little and then fix them back in orbit. They'd spread enough radiation around as I take off to kill any bacteria that have decided to get comfy here.

No, no, I'll just spew radioactive exhaust everywhere... no, I need that fuel to get into orbit. Umm...

Actually, now that I think of it, the NTR has an emergency dump valve to get eject excess radiation out and away from the vehicle. I can use that. Yeah, that'll work. I hope. Jet engines should blast the waste along the ground as I fly past, too.

And if that doesn't work, I may have accidentally advanced the space program of the uncommon cold far faster than we'd anticipated would ever be possible. Hell, those lousy germs would have a colony on Laythe before us! Because of me! Ok, time to wipe the b******s out!

Sparrowhawk Comp: [EMERGENCY RADIATION RELEASE VALVE OPEN. SHUT AT YOUR DISCRETION]

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Muahaha...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That should do it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sparrowhawk Comp: [RADIATION RELEASE VALVE CLOSED. CORE REGAINING STABILITY]

And these blue clouds... probably not very healthy, but they're damn cool. Some sort of smog, perhaps?

I'll be back soon, Laythe. Just gotta top up the old fuel tanks, you kn Ã¢â‚¬â€œ oh Kod.

Oh wow. That's one hell of a view.

Rocket, dumbass.

Oh yeah. Thanks, subconscious me.

No problem.

Meanwhile, on Enterprise...

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey Dean.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, hey. What you up to, there?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Lengas is still busy working on the ship, so I've been looking at all the Tylo samples that Jim collected.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Anything interesting?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, pretty good stuff, but then again, I'm a geologist. We tend to get excited over things like this. I'm not sure how much you'd enjoy looking at a breccia slide under a microscope for hours on end, heh.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ha, fair enough. Where is Jim, anyway?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I think he's in one of the greenhouses, trying to gather his thoughts. He's still a little p***** off.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm. I'll take my chances, I haven't spoken to him for a few days.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good luck.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean floats from the hab to the greenhouse access corridor and checks in each before finding Jim curled up in the corner of the number 3 greenhouse.

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey Jim, you alright?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, it's just you. I swear to Kod, I thought Mac was coming to bother me again.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“He is pretty annoying, isn't he?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Uh-huh. Anyway, I'm doing better, I guess. I'm in here trying to calm down, if you're wondering.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, Matt said. No better place to try, either, eh? The view in here is pretty sweet.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's why I'm here, plus the plants are quite comforting.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I hope you haven't damaged any of them lest ye incur the wrath of Ed.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hah. No, I've been careful to avoid irritating Ed, too. I don't think I'd live much longer if I angered both the medics on this ship... I don't get how anyone can put up with Mac. Hell, even Jeb got pretty screwy with him when mediating your fights.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I guess he's just one of those people. Don't get me wrong, I know I did play a part, however small, in... souring our opinions of each other, but he really did the most damage.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know. Not letting you talk to Buzz was ridiculous.

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It was. I'm just thankful Buzz got better. Mac's got no ammunition against me now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“At least you stood up to him. Nobody should be bullied around like that. Hmph, that's probably why I threw the punch at Matt, earlier. I imagine he's not too happy with me. It was intended for Mac, but Matt sort of... got there first.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Would you have hit him anyway?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Only if he didn't leave me alone after I'd got Mac.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm... listen, you just chill out a little more, ok? I think Evil Jim isn't as nice a person as the Jim I know.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Evil Jim, hah, good one. Go on, before I get my death ray out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Dean: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Heh. Just shout me if you want to chat, or something.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Will do, man.Ã¢â‚¬Â
Interesting. Can't see where this is going.

CHAPTER 50: SCIENTIFIC PURSUITS

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s nothing at the foot of the ladder, right?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, no, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s fine.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No re-freezing ice that melted as a result of the engine exhaust?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“UhÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ noÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re not tricking me into slipping, are you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“There may be a little crater, but itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not hazardous.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, but if I trip and twist my ankle, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m coming to get you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right, thanks for the heads up.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm, not bad. YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re safe.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Phew.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, I must say, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s quite dark out here. Oddly beautiful, but dark.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It is, but it makes sense being this far from the Sun.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know that. Inverse-square law and what-not.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Inverse-what now?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know that?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m coming out now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Got it, Ed. Yeah, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m not sure what this law is. I may do if you refresh my memory.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh dear. Basically, you double the distance and the amount of light decreases by a factor of four. The lawÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s applicable to other scenarios, too.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Huh. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d guess thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s because of the curvature of the Sun, right?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm, you learn something new every day.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Z-Level Physics, how could you not know that?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Wow, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s nice out here. What are you two talking about?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Bill didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know the inverse-square law.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: *GASP* Ã¢â‚¬Å“My Kod!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh that makes me feel a lot better, knowing a medic slash biologist has a better understanding of this physics than I do.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s basic Z-Level stuff, though!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I specialised in orbital mechanics, sort of shoving a lot of other stuff out the way to make room. I guess this inverse-square law just didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t make the cut.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh man.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Not that it matters. The main implication is for solar power, which anyone should be acutely aware of, really.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“YesÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ well, letÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not take the mick out of poor old Bill any longer and get to work, shall we? Ed, youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re on the drill. Franklin, you get samples from some of these boulders, and IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll have a look further afield.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Cool.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“So, you just want me to hammer away at this thing, because it doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t look very well held together.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t think it matters, just chisel away at it and pick up the best pieces.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s easy enoughÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ What is it, a granite or something?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s what weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re here to find out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm.Ã¢â‚¬Â

MeanwhileÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll just be at the top of this hill, guys.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Gotcha.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Those mountains are pretty impressive. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a shame we didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t land a bit closer.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“On the other hand, we landed safely.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We could probably have managed it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Eh, maybe.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t like mountains, do you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Not quite that. I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t like flying over mountains.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Why not?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I had anÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ accident, once. Nasty crash. My dad took me flying in his Shessna 121 when I was a kid. We went over the range by that big crater, flying fairly low but within reason. Then a gust of wind hit us and we went tumbling. My dad only just recovered the plane in time to save the cabinÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ mostly. The undercarriage was wrecked, the right wing torn off, the propellers twisted and the engines in pieces. The canopy was shattered and the controls destroyed. When we finally settled, I got off lucky; all I came out with was a broken leg and a concussion. My dad, being on the right-hand side of the plane, wound up with a cracked skull, broken ribs, legs, some internal bleeding, and a concussion to boot. I got out of the hospital in days but my dad was there for months while they fixed him up.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“KodÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I felt bad that he had to stay in longer than I, but he felt worse that IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d even been hurt. He never quite recovered from that crash, and the fact that I could well have died never strayed far from his thoughts. Of course, I hold nothing against him and IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve told him plenty of times that heÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s got nothing to feel bad for. I can only hope he does recover eventually. ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s what made me want to become a medic, so I could help people like my dad. ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s also what made me apprehensive about flying over mountains, so youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll have to forgive my attitude regarding the matter.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ed, I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t know what to say.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s nothing to say, so donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t worry about it. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s something that happened to me and IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m trying to get over it, but that sort of apprehension is tough to shake off.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I understand that. Thanks for sharing that with us, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s, uhÃ¢â‚¬Â¦ itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not every day that someone comes out with a story like that. If you need to talk, then just come and see me, alright?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Or me, for that matter. IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve lost friends in plane crashes, so it might do good to have someone who can relate to you on the subject.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You guys, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s nothing, really! IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m fine. Hell, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m here, on Vall! A moon of Jool, so far from Kerbin. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a big step for me, and while I appreciate the thoughts tremendously, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m not in need of counselling. Regardless, I thank you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re welcome.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Anyway, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll get back to this core drill now, if you donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t mind.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, yeah, go for itÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: *Under breath* Ã¢â‚¬Å“DamnÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Several hours laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ugh, the landerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s lights have gone out. WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve just got our suits until sunrise.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Crap. I hope that doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t mean itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s completely out of power.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I think itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s on the back-up batteries in the command module.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s nothing serious, theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll power the scientific instruments and basic life support, plus the solar panel tracking systems. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not like this hasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t happened in the past. It happened a fair bit when I was on Duna.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s quite eerie out here now, though.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It wasnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t already?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“At least we could see beforehand.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We can see now, canÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t we?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“True.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Watch out, guys, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m coming in.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I see you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, so what now?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I was sort of hoping youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢d be telling us that, seeing as you are the commander, after all.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“HmmÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t think we can take off on emergency power, can we? The control instrumentation will be mostly offline.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“WeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll need to wait for dawn. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a few hours at most. I think, in the meantime, we can get more samples and data.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That sounds like a good idea. Just donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t lose sight of each other, and watch your step.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t need to tell me twice.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A short while laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“There, the powerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s back on the lander. We can go if you want, Bill.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Very well. LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s pack up our stuff and go home.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“The core drill just needs to finish this sample and then IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll be done.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ll come and give you a hand once youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re done with it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ed: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few minutes laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Darn, poor Ed.

Keep up the good work!

CHAPTER 51: JEBÃ¢â‚¬â„¢S CONTINUING MISSION

LaytheÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t worry Laythe, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m coming back, now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

The moons here are beautiful. I love the view here.

A short while laterÃ¢â‚¬Â¦

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“LetÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s just hope the heat shields hold up a second timeÃ¢â‚¬Â¦Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Wow, that smog is thick here. CanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t see muÃ¢â‚¬â€Ã¢â‚¬Å“

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ã¢â‚¬Â¦Sh*t.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Sparrowhawk Comp: [TEMPERATURE PEAKING. NO MAJOR DAMAGE DETECTED. REPLACE HEATSHIELD]
